reviewText:
To my fellow former Alien Swarm junkies: Helldivers is the closest you're going to get to filling your fix. The short of this review is that Helldivers is a brilliant parody of Starship Troopers and the right-wing military-industrial complex, with a healthy dose of Warhammer 40K xenophobia and vehicle design, fused together into a solid A-grade twin-stick co-op shooter.

The good/game overview
The game shares some surface similarities with Alien Swarm, but it handles completely differently. It's made by the creators of Magicka, and it really shows. Characters move and turn more slowly while aiming, but are also able to sprint and hit the deck to avoid enemy fire. Deaths and teamkilling (there is much teamkilling, so don't be mad when it happens) aren't the end of the world, as there is a team resurrect spell" like there is in Magicka in the form of reinforcements. Indeed
date: "spellcasting" is one of the game's most defining featues.\n\nIn Magicka
recommended: players can cast spells by pressing combinations of different elements using the QWER/ASDF keys
hoursPlayed: each key representing earth
voteText: fire
helpfulPercent: water
votesHelpful: etc. That system has been brought over to Helldivers in the form of the radio. The player can press a button to open up the radio and dial in codes for support assets using the WASD keys. What support assets
votesTotal: called "stratagems"
votesFunny: are available to the player is chosen at the start of the game when everyone is selecting their loadouts. Stratagems vary from heavy weapons such as machine guns and rocket launchers
commentsCount: backpack items such as jetpacks and ammo bags
column16: vehicles such as mech suits and tanks
column17: and fire support like bombing runs and orbital strikes.\n\nThis system is interesting because the player is unable to perform combat actions while interacting with the radio
column18: making it very difficult to use in combat unless you get down the muscle memory or are able to get cover from the squad while you dial in the code. This is very important for stratagems like reinforcement and fire support
column19: which can either result in you saving the day or dying miserably after dialing an incorrect code.\n\nMissions appear to be randomly generated in a pre-made open map. That is to say
column20: there is a variety of different objective types
column21: and the locations
column22: number
column23: and types of objectives you must complete are randomly selected based on the difficulty level. Difficulty ranges from level 1 all the way up to level 12
column24: and the harder the difficulty
column25: the more objectives and more enemies there are to deal with. Rewards scale
column26: as one might expect — more powerful stratagems are unlocked at the higher difficulties
column27: and the opportunities to collect the science points used to upgrade your arsenal are more common.\n\nThe reward for difficulty level 12 is a special cape that shows your mettle to other players. There is a character customization system that is 100% cosmetic-only and is a surefire way to make your character look like the badass he or she is as a warrior of the Federation. Weapons and stratagems unlock by leveling up and completing missions
column28: and the number of ones that are actually useful and balanced is actually pretty decent. Like any game
column30: but there are enough useful ones to allow the player to create a play style that is totally different from their squadmate's and still be completely viable. All things considered
column31: that's pretty impressive.\n\nAn awesome feature of this game is the ability to mix local and online multiplayer. If you connect your computer to the TV
column32: you can have a couple friends join with Xbox controllers and bring in a fourth person over the Internet. More games need to do this.\n\nAll of this takes place in the context of a galactic war metagame. Completing missions grants "community influence"
column33: points that contribute towards beating back the enemy. Humanity is waging a very fine and just war among three different fronts against three enemies
column34: each of which can eventually be defeated and removed from the war. So far
column35: I've yet to see this happen
column36:
but it is interesting. It's also where the character of the game and its hilarious Starship Troopers influence is at its best.

The bad
As mentioned earlier
column37: missions are randomly generated based on difficulty. The consequence is a total lack of structured story missions of the kind found in Alien Swarm or many other co-op games. While this on the one hand can keep the player on their toes
column38: the drawback is that it's somewhat uninteresting and can get tiresome doing different variants of essentially the same mission structure.\n\nThe galactic war being tied to unlocks is interesting
column39: but it also has a couple drawbacks. One
column40: it's boring playing through baby-level missions to get a piece of essential equipment. Becoming skilled enough to get the high-level ones will come with time.\n\nThe other more significant downside is that because the war is always shifting
column41: different planets with different unlocks become available and others disappear. After almost 100 hours as of time of writing
column42: I have still yet to unlock the anti-personnel landmines because I can never find a planet that offers it as a mission reward. I have plenty of other equipment and can easily live without it in ordinary missions of any difficulty
column43: but it's still somewhat annoying and it especially reduces my usefulness to approximately zero in a particular boss battle in which mines are essential equipment.\n\nThere is also a hefty amount of equipment that is restricted behind a DLC paywall. A lot of it is useless
column44: a lot of it is useful
column46: such as the mech mounting an anti-tank cannon
column47: are borderline pay-to-win. Satchel charges help a lot against bosses and holdout missions
column48: and all-terrain boots make your life a lot easier walking in snow. There is plenty of different equipment in the base game that can approach the same task differently and just as effectively — for example
column49: the armored car with heavy cannon in the base game can do the same job as the DLC anti-tank mech
column50: and it even has significantly more ammunition — but it's very difficult to safely deploy in combat to bail the team out of a losing situation
column51: which is something the mech can do with ease.\n\nFinally
column52: while mixed local/online play is awesome
column53: playing with a gamepad is not. Using a mouse and keyboard
column54: the player is afforded a crosshair while holding down the aim button
column55: and punching in radio codes with the WASD keys is efficient and smooth. Using a gamepad
column56: there is no way to precisely judge aim without a laser sight equipped
column57: costing the player a very valuable inventory slot. Meanwhile
column58: the directional pad on the Xbox 360 controller that most PC gamers use if they have one is also subpar
column59: and that's bad news when using the radio
column60: which requires fast correct inputs under high pressure; the d-pad makes this difficult
column61:
to say the least.

Conclusion/tl;dr
Good things
Solid twin-stick shooter mechanics
Hilarious Starship Troopers-inspired setting
Magicka-inspired radio "spellcasting" system
Varied and versatile unlocks
Galactic war metagame creates a sense of community
Mixed local and online multiplayer
Bad things
Galactic war metagame can make it either easy
column63:
or boring to get specific unlocks
Randomly-generated missions can get stale
Lots of DLC equipment in varying levels of usefulness
Subpar experience if using a gamepad instead of a keyboard and mouse
Verdict: A
Twin-stick shooter fans
column65: and Alien Swarm fans will find a home in Helldivers. If you're none of these
column66: consider giving it a go anyway with Steam refunds in mind. I have several friends who aren't twin-stick shooter fans who had a lot of fun with it. While it has a few weaknesses
column67:
the overall game is a shining co-op experience.

Update April 2016
At my character limit

reviewText: I am posting here hoping to reach  people or the devs to inform people about the negative review regarding the DLC. I have noticed that many of the recent negative reviews, including the top, most helpful review, is bashing Helldivers for their DLC practice". Mainly being that they think there is no way to upgrade from the regular edition to the DDE edition if you bought the standard edition/vanguard edition previously. The negative reviews stem from that fact that they believe the only way to acquire the DLC is to purchase all the DLC separately costing more than double the base game. This is not the case. The mega reinforcement pack costs $25. Adding this pack to the standard/vanguard preorder edition means you are paying $45 versus the $40 DDE
date: hardly a difference worth complaining over.\n\nTo the devs
recommended: the mega reinforcement pack is pretty hidden in the DLC page and I only came across it by chance. If you were perhaps more transparent with this purchasing option
hoursPlayed: I am sure it would calm many of the negative reviews. Some ways to do this would be to adverstise this DLC pack on the main store page before all the individual ones and also referring to it as a DDE upgrade. Perhaps even just responding to the top negative review right now explaining this would help others see that your game is fantastic and that the "DLC practice" is not screwing over those that pre-ordered the Vanguard edition. I am commenting here in hopes of keeping Helldiver's from losing its overwhelmingly positive rating that it deserves over something as simple as a misunderstanding and obscure buying option of the mega reinforcement pack."

reviewText:
As a fan of Alien Swarm, i really liked this game. It's a top down co-op shooter at its finest. Arrived at the scene, complete the objectives, then wait for extraction. Failed one of the objectives? Not a big deal soldier, get your ♥♥♥ to the extraction point and live to fight another day!

In this game, you are a Helldiver. You, alone or with friends or strangers, will be deployed to a planet, which you can choose, and try to complete missions in those planets. Each missions is procedurally generated and has its own objectives. Some of the objectives are specific to an enemy race, but sadly there are not a lot of variety on it. Everytime you complete a planet, you will gain some influence points. And then you jump to other planet, complete the missions, then gain another influence points. These influence points are important to take over regions, and when all the regions are under Super Earth control, then you can participate in an event, the final push to enemy's home world, to defeat them once and for all.

As you rise through the ranks to become the Admiral of Super Earth and helping Super Earth to regain control of the galaxy, you will unlock weapons, stratagems, and perks to help you eradicate your space adversaries. Each weapons and stratagems can be upgraded by using research points, which can be gained by getting samples while you are on the field, or by simply ranking up. Oh, and you can also change your appearance, by the way. Just saying.

Although advanced or modified weapons and stratagems helps (a lot), but teamwork is still the most important thing if you want to complete all the objectives, especially in harder difficulties. Even a Private can help a lot, as long as that person isn't dicking around. Stick to your teammates, move as a team, all of you must become a unit to be successful. Obviously the devs had this in mind, so in order to make all the players work together, they decided to lock the camera, so you and your teammates can't wander too far from each other. I understand and actually liked the camera lock, but sometimes the camera lock can be annoying since it limit your view.

As you can expect from the creators of Magicka, you will die, a lot. But if you are looking for stupid and hilarious accidental deaths, then you are gonna be a little bit disappointed. It's an accidental death, so yeah there is a funny side to it. But there are not much variations of it, and when sometimes in Magicka you can be overwhelmed by the combinations and you can accidentally killed yourself or your friends, in this one that's just not gonna happen. I guess i just expected too much in this aspect.

In terms of performance, so far so good. Constant 60fps. Never had an issue, no CTD, no sudden lag. Lack graphical options, but i can't say i expect more.

In the end, HELLDIVERS is a fun game. I had fun with randoms, and i'm sure it will be even more fun to play with friends. The upgrade system add a bit of depth, and the influence system made the game more immersive, although to understand it completely i think you need a bit of googling.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

TL;DR, A fun top down, twin-stick, whatever-you-call-it shooter. A great PC port, stable performance. Try Alien Swarm, it's free, if you like it, then there is a big chance you'll like this too.

reviewText: Don't let the big red thumbs down fool you. This game is great! It's a lot of fun, very challenging and it's got some really nice attention to detail but I have to give a Not Recommended" due to the DLC practices and the lack of information on the way DLC is handled.\n\nRight now the base game is the game
date: the three free content "expansions"(They didn't add much to warrant naming them expansions; three new unit types
hoursPlayed: three new mission types and a new planet) and that's it. The DDE gives you all the DLC for an extra €10 which you probably won't buy considering you wouldn't think the DLC included in the DDE is 1. Every single bit of DLC on offer and 2. Wouldn't impact the game to make it significantly easier(Or P2W).\n\nThe DLCs itself is a mixed bag. Some of them look pretty useless unless you really want the cosmetic gear but some of them seem like must haves and would make the game incredibly easy by comparison with those who have the base game. The only option to get what the DDE nets you other than buying the DDE outright? Well
voteText: if you look at the store page it lists all DLC for €43. Don't let that fool you
helpfulPercent: the devs cheekily hid the cheaper option that nets you all DLC for €20 called the "Reinforcements Mega Pack" and the only way to get to it is to check individual DLCs and scroll down a bit until the pack is viewable. Even at that
votesHelpful: that's twice as much as the DDE would have cost you. Is there any option to upgrade to the DDE? Nope! None. Why not? Because they obviously want to get as much money from you as possible upon realising your foolishness in bot spending the full €30 on the game to begin with with little to no information(If you pre-ordered) on the DLCs on offer.\n\nIt will only be after you play the game
votesTotal: get in and see how much needed some of the DLC is that you'll realise how screwed over you were and how the DLC makes the game P2W. It makes it considerably easier with abilities that give auto targeting to instant kill tank units where base "Strategems" require you to land these barrages on top of the target and time it to land within three seconds or so. Don't want the hassle? Pay for the Precision DLC pack: Anti-Tank/Armoured missiles will auto target the tanks or armoured units if they're on the same screen where the base "vanilla" DLC lands right on top of where you drop the beacon.\n\nHow about Anti-Tank mechs or tanks? Well
votesFunny: for the price of €4 you can unlock an anti-tank mech
commentsCount:
a massive overpowered tank and a two man motor-bike for funsies! Or you could have paid €10 extra before you bought the game and gotten EVERYTHING included. Pity... now your only option is to pay for DLC individually or pay €20 to get what the DDE would have given you.

It's pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ especially to those of us who pre-ordered and had no idea what the DLC was or how it would affect gameplay or how much easier it would make things or give you a massive boost in progression. You get a tank if you pay for it. You won't know it until you actually play the game for a while but there isn't a tank in the game. The DLC is the only way to get the tank!

It's a really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ practice and there should have been more information given to us when we were asked to pay up but they didn't. They just listed DLC packs
column16: no information on them and gave the illusion that the pre-order bonus of the Ranger DLC was unique but it's not... It's probably the more useless packs in the game.\n\nThe game is fantastic but if you're going to get it and think you'll love it just spend the extra €10 otherwise you're going to be feeling really sour about your purchase."

reviewText:
Day 1:
I bought the game.
Seems to be pretty cool.
Easy missions are a bore, but i actually found some people communicative enough and we worked as a team.
Propably gonna get back to the game next day, so far so good.

Day 2:
Start the game.
Well i just joined a team of 3 and they suggested we do the helldive mission (hardest difficulty).
Why the hell not, but i thought i'd only slow them down.
We freaking ace the mission, everybody escapes, every objective is done, we cheer each other up, telling how good it was and stuff.
Some guys tell me how cool that was that i saved them all a couple times, while being almost dead myself.
Feels pretty cool.
So that's the true side of this game, huh?

Day 3:
I find even more people to play with and add them to steam.
We go for some hard missions.
Get our ♥♥♥♥ wrecked several times by the damn tank bugs, who circled us.
Run around the objective wrecking hell and havoc around, ressurecting your buddies and throwing stuff around.
I started noticing how i meet the same people which is kind of cool. Sure the community is comparatively small (about 2-3k around the steam + some people on reddit and other forums), but there's a charm in that, because you meet familiar faces who you've already fought along with and you go on new adventures and stuff.
+ the voice-active fellas are a pretty common thing in this game and they talk mostly tactical or just fun ♥♥♥♥, no trash-talk or anything. To be honest i'm yet to see one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who ruins the mission in this game, mostly it's just ♥♥♥♥'n'giggles that we die to.

Day 4:
Tried soloing some missions, did pretty good.
Decided to buy DLC, because at least one is a must (the all-terrain pack, snow planets are a pain in the ♥♥♥ without the boots perk).
The price stings, but why the hell not, i'm having fun with the game.
Join another group of guys and we complete a full Helldive planet and get the legendary cape.
Feels good.
Also we defeated the bugs homeworld and are about to capture the cyborgs.
I decided to try out the cyborg planets as i was mostly playing the bugs before.
Join the random game and feel the sudden urge to cry FOR THE EMPEROR" as i spawn my mech and run around exploding tanks
date: butchers and other enemies.\nThere is indeed a strong warhammer feel to that
recommended: just like there is a "Starship troopers" feel to every bug planet.\nCyborgs are tough though
hoursPlayed: so we die a lot
voteText: but still manage to do this.\nAfter about 16 hours of gameplay i still have some equipment that i haven't got
helpfulPercent:
which is cool.

Day 5:
So i woke up
votesHelpful:
did some stuff and decided to do a quick run.
Oh boy was i wrong.
I join a "helldive" server on cyborg planet.

reviewText:
This game, despite having a few major flaws, it still pretty fun for a while. I wanted to write an informative negative review about something other than complaining about the DLC or controls, which is what almost all the other negative reviews are about.

In my opinion, there are three major things wrong with this game:
1.  On higher difficulties, the game revolves largely around avoiding being detected by scouts but the mechanics of the scouts are dull and sometimes frustrating. This is by far the biggest problem with Helldivers.

On the higher difficulties, mission success is very, very reliant on remaining mostly undetected.  The map has wandering scouts, who call for backup if they are not killed within about 2 seconds of being alerted.  Their sight range is about half a screen length, so they can sound the alarm within 2 seconds of appearing on the edge of your screen.  This itself is not a problem, but . . .

In multiplayer, all characters are locked on the screen and can not move the camera independently.  However, the scouts' alert range remains the same.  The result is that the scouts can sound the alarm from off-screen, unless the players are traveling in a tight group in the center of the screen, practically shoulder to shoulder, which is very hard to do unless you're playing with friends who are good at co-operating.  This makes the multiplayer awkward and frustrating at times.

Because the game revolves so much around not getting detected, players must stop and press TAB to open the map every few seconds to try see the approaching scouts on the map before they appear on screen.  Some players bring lots of ammo (or a weapon that doesn't consume ammo) and shoot them off-screen.  This kind of gameplay gets very, very stale within a few hours, yet it's what you'll be spending 90% of your time doing if you play on the highest difficulty.

As a result of all this, it's much easier to play the game alone, so your character is center-screen and scouts can never catch you by surprise.  You'll still be opening the map every 5 seconds, to make sure you're not facing the wrong direction when they come.  Playing alone gets boring.  A game that encourages playing alone has problems.

This could be mostly fixed by making each players camera move independently, or completely changing the alert mechanics, preferably the latter.

On top of all this, once you do start soloing, or playing with a group that's decent at killing scouts, the game becomes way too easy.  No one should be able to consistently solo the hardest difficulty within their first 20 hours on a game, yet after about 20 hours of play, soloing the hardest difficulty was so easy to me that it became boring.  I may have been able to do it even earlier had I thought to attempt it.

2.  The controls are awkward.  This is more of a problem for newer players, because you do get used to the awkward controls eventually, but it makes the first few hours of play much less enjoyable than they would be otherwise.  Also, because the scouts sound the alarm very quickly, being able to shoot them as fast as possible is very important, and the awkward controls add a very not-fun layer of difficulty to this.  Awkward controls shouldn't be used to add difficulty to a game, unless it's in a hilarous and fun way such as Magicka's spell casting system.

With mouse and keyboard, the awkwardness comes from the fact that the cross-hair does not show up on the screen while the player is not aiming down their sights (which greatly slows your move speed).  The cross-hair also resets to the middle of your screen (or a few feet in front of your character, if you use that option) every time you stop aiming down sights.  The result is cumbersome and unintuitive aiming controls that frequently make you lose track of your cross-hair.  It also forces you to pick up and move your mouse a lot.  The white cross-hair is also difficult to see in some maps.
A lot of players are suggesting that the cross-hair be always visible, which would certainly help, and it sounds like the developers are considering it.

On a gamepad, it's simply difficult to know where you're aiming, and difficult to aim precisely.  Often you'll see gamepad players fire a couple rounds just to see where they're aiming, then adjust their aim on target and fire again, effectively using their first few bullets as a laser pointer.  Of course, you can run with the laser pointer perk all the time (and many gamepad users do this) but this limits your loadout significantly.  Aiming feels so much better with the laser pointer perk (and so bad without it) that I think it should be there by default and not take up your perk slot.

3.  Some important (but not essential) items are sold as DLC.There are a few items in the DLC packs that are very helpful, although it's still very possible to manage without them.  I dislike when games sell important items as DLC.
The items I'm referring to are the UAV drone, All Terrain Boots, and Exo-51 Lumberer Exosuit.  Most of the other DLC items are not game changing, and many of them are hardly ever used.

At this point, I've probably made this game sound pretty bad.  Helldivers was still pretty fun for the first 30 hours or so, but the lack of difficulty and poor stealth mechanics make the game get stale much faster than I would have liked.  With some changes, I could easily see myself playing Helldivers for hundreds of hours and rating it as one of my favourite games.

So this review is based off roughly 100+ hours of playing this on PS4 combined with just over 3 hours of playing on PC to ensure the port is good... well it's not good.... it's ♥♥♥♥ing Great
For those who love a stick shooter, you should know nothing more just buy this game.   Get a group of friends and just roll with it, and you will be surprised at how much fun you have.

PROS
Steam integration seems fantastic
great in game VOIP system
Easy to play with friends, and kick toxic players
Game runs very well on PC from low res window to 4k and it looks great
Wonderful Humor, art style, etc... it captures both Murica & a starship troopers vibe
Gameplay has a lot more depth as you will continue to dive in.  Classes, weapon rolls, you will soon find out team composition matters
Rewarding and challenging in the right ways
Friendly FIRE is awesome and hilarious
Just one of the best top down coop experiences ever created
CONS
Some people might buy DLC right away, I would say wait as it's really made for seasoned players to hop back into
Best when played with friends.. so loners might not get the full experience
Overall, this game offers a lot and at a $20 entry fee, your money will be well spent.

reviewText:
Bringing democracy to the galaxy, one planet at a time!
Helldivers is a hardcore twin-stick co-op shooter developed by Arrowhead Studios. After launching on PlayStation consoles back in March, Helldivers is at last making an appearance on Steam. In Helldivers you play as a helldiver (you don’t say) trying to rid the galaxy of three enemy factions to protect Super Earth and all of its wonderful, freedom loving inhabitants! The more freedom you deliver to the galaxy, the more cool stuff you unlock in the form of armour, weapons and stratagems (I’ll explain this in more detail later on).

Full Disclosure: A review copy was provided by the developer.

Presentation
Helldivers is a good looking game with great design. I’m not really sure what you’d call the style of graphics this game but you can tell from the screenshots it looks good. As I said everything is well designed, particularly the enemies, and everything looks good even from the camera angle in the game. The UI is clean and simple, effectively giving the player all the info they need. It can sometimes get in the way of things if you’re towards the bottom of the screen but it’s translucent and can be scaled so it’s not too bad. One thing that a minority (I think it’s fair to call it that judging by the positive to negative review ratios) have been up in arms about is the fact that the game is screen-locked, meaning you all four players are on screen at all times and the camera moves to make this possible. While the argument against it has its merits (see forum threads if you’re interested) I thought it was a good design choice. That doesn’t mean I particularly like being screen-locked, what I do like though is how it forces the players to work together which is incredibly important in this game.

Gameplay
In Helldivers your aim is to wipe out the three enemy factions to ensure Super Earth’s safety. This is done by reaching the home-worlds of each faction and taking them out. At the time of writing this review we haven’t reached the home-worlds in the current galaxy campaign and so I’m not actually sure what these home-world missions entail. So what’s this galaxy campaign? The galaxy campaign is what you see when you look at the map on your ship. Each sector between Super Earth and an enemy home-world requires the players to earn a certain amount of influence by completing missions in said sector. The galaxy campaign is shared by PC users as well as PlayStation players and resets when all three factions are wiped out or Super Earth falls. If a previously held sector is about to be re-captured by an enemy faction a City defence event is triggered which lasts for just over an hour and awards double exp for every mission done. If enough influence is earned the sector is held.

Now onto the missions which you’ll be doing more regularly than that. Each planet in a given sector is randomly generated, has a difficulty level between one and twelve (twelve being the hardest), has between two and four missions and has a reward for the player upon completing all missions. The missions themselves require you to complete certain objectives such as performing a geological survey or escorting some stranded humans to a safe location. Some of these objectives, as well as your stratagems, require you to enter a combination of keys to complete it, basically a QTE. This is another thing that some people don’t like and while I wouldn’t say it’s my favourite part of the game I did like it being there, it adds a nice bit of variety to the gameplay.

So what are those stratagem things I mentioned earlier? These are defensive, offensive and equipment based drops which aid you in completing your mission. An example of a defensive stratagem is a machinegun turret that fires at enemies (and you if you’re in the way). There are also objective specific stratagems which are available to you when necessary.

The last thing worth mentioning for gameplay is the fact the game has friendly fire. Generally one or two shots won’t damage you but anything more than that is going to do serious damage and might even kill you so you have to keep an eye out at all times. Another thing that some people have a serious problem with. I don’t think anyone, apart from the very tiny population of trolls, would say that they like having friendly fire but this is a hardcore game and this does make it more challenging so I personally wouldn’t want to see it go.

Miscellaneous The last thing that people have a problem with (this is where the negative reviews come from) is the control scheme for KB&M. How it works is that your crosshair is only visible when aiming with the RMB and when aiming your movement and turn speed is decreased. I wasn’t keen on this to begin with though I did get used to it. I can understand why people are so against this as it is rather hard to get used to but once you have gotten used to it I think it’s pretty good. The devs have said they’ll consider changing it but the reason it’s like this is because the ways they tried it with the crosshairs on made using KB&M significantly easier than using a gamepad.
There’s not a huge amount of it but the voice acting in the game is good. The majority of the dialogue in the game comes from your characters’ one liners such as “How do you like the taste of freedom?” or “Would you like a cup of liber-tea”. They are rather amusing though can get irritating, thankfully there’s an option to turn them off!
There are quite a lot of weapons and stratagems to unlock and they all have upgrades purchased with research points earned by gathering science samples or levelling up.
Each faction is made up of quite a few enemies, each with a very different combat style.
Solo play is possible but some of the in-game objectives are incredibly difficult to do without help.
Verdict
Essential Purchase.

Helldivers is an outstandingly good hardcore co-op game that manages to be incredibly challenging and fun at the same time.

No drama, Just Reviews.

El K.

reviewText:
This is one of the most hardcore co-op games I've ever played.

Be prepared for friendly-fire from your teammates, your teammates' turrets, your support drops, your teammate's support drops, etc... Everything deals damage to you, and the game plays like a couch co-op game when multiple people are in a game, where the camera is focused in on the host while everybody else moves around within the confines of that camera's field of view.

Helldivers is an absolute blast to play with friends, randoms online, or even yourself. The game is balanced well in singleplayer, where you're given more than one life, but it's still best played online so you can experience the various unique mechanics that make teamwork as necessary as it is. It's not anywhere near as simple as evading enemies and spraying bullets all over the place like most twin-stick shooters. Instead, you'll find yourself picking your targets before firing, and ensuring that no teammates are going to get caught in the crossfire. Leveling up also rewards you with upgrade points and new gear to spend them on, allowing for an even more diverse group of helldivers ready to take on the game's strongest foes. There's also a lot of time management and cover fire necessary to throw out the various abilities you can select from, as they're cast with unique button combinations, and required for necessary functions such as reviving teammates and supplying your team with more ammunition.

On top of the great looking visuals and audio, online voice chat quality is top notch, and there's text-based chat as well.

You're getting a ton of content for your money with the vanilla version of the game. It's well worth every penny.

reviewText:
I've put a pretty good amount of time into this game, and I can honestly say I enjoyed almost all of it.

So, why the negative review?

Well, I'll tell you why. And no, it doesn't have anything to do with DLC that was pushed out in the year prior to it's PC release or the porting from the PS3. (Although frankly those will be issues for some people. Read the other reviews if you want more on those issues.)

There are three reasons I can't recommend this title.

1) The price.

The base game's price of $20 is about what it would be worth with all the DLC included. Why is that, you ask? Namely because after you unlock all of the Stratagem (you should have them all by level 25-30 out of 50 levels, without farming, which should be roughly 40-60 hours) the gameplay becomes monotonous in the extreme. By the time you're level 15-20, you'll likely have every stratagem you'll ever use if you choose wisely.

The maps are randomly generated, and that's a wonderful attempt to make each map feel unique, but all it really does is slightly alter the shape of the map and the location of a small selection of objectives to complete. It could have been amazing if there were either more enemy types or more types of planet to fight on, but there simply aren't enough of them to make the RNG of map generation feel that meaningful to me. It's still just a volcanic world, an ice world, a desert world, or a forest world, or if you're super lucky a city map once in a blue moon.

2) Overly repetitive content.

There are only 3 enemy types, and 5 'biomes'. One biome, the city map, only opens in the rare circumstance when you lose a sector of space, and is only open for two hours, so really there are only 4 biomes you'll see on a regular basis.

That's pretty bare bones, but to make it even worse there are only a few types of objective too. While the RNG map creation does switch things up, that's more a matter of placement vs. what you're actually doing. Also, while there are many 'Stratagem' abilities only a handful of those abilities are useful for the limited amount of objectives in the game.

Eventually, you realize that the only objectives that provide even a slight challenge are defense style objectives and among those only three provide any actual challenge. Even among those three, each of them are defused from 'slightly hard' to 'effortless' simply by using the Distractor Beacon. (Which, by the way, should be properly labeled 'EZ Mode' since it effectively breaks the entire game by allowing you to lure all patrols to an area where your team isn't.)

If that wasn't bad enough, you don't even need the Distractor beacon. On high difficulty modes, it isn't actually any harder than the easiest difficulty modes. The difference between Difficulty 1 and Difficulty 12 is mostly negligible as long as you kill the patrols since if you kill any patrol you come across you never spawn any enemies. The patrols don't become appreciably harder between 1-12, so effectively there is no difference once you're used to the game.

Essentially, the game will feel very 'carebear' past 50+ hours and the only mitigation to that are new or bad players joining your game that don't understand the mechanics of shooting patrols in a timely fashion.

This becomes even more problematic when you start to realize that the biggest threat to you in Helldivers is actually your own team. On top of that, there is absolutely no way to filter your lobby so that level 1 people can't drop into your helldive mission. In my opinion that's pretty unforgivable since I can't even begin to tell you how many level 1-5 players have dropped into my missions only to immediately shoot everyone and instantly lose the map. Sometimes, it's funny and awesome but a lot of the time it's just griefing or annoying. Not to say I don't like the TK element, because I definitely do, but a new or even intermediate player is just as likely to take your head off as an enemy.

3) War Campaign Mechanics

This could have been a really great thing, and in theory it sounds good. With each map you complete, you add points to a total for that sector of space. Everyone's maps in that sector count towards the goal, and once the total is high enough you conquer that sector. You conquer each area of space leading up to an enemy homeworld, then you assault their homeworld and knock them out. That sounds great, right?

It does until you realize that once you take out that homeworld, you can not fight that faction again until the war is over. This means that if you like to fight bugs, too bad once they're out. You won't see them again, or be able to fight them again, for a week or longer.

Instead, you'll be forced to fight the other two factions until they're completely defeated, which can and will take days or even weeks to complete. It's also no coincidence that the order in which the planets are generally defeated have been Bugs > Cyborgs > Illuminate, and believe me when all you can fight is the Illuminate you're going to start questioning your sanity pretty quickly since all the other problems I've mentioned above are magnified given that each homeworld has a set biome type. (Ice for Cyborg, Forest for Illuminate, Desert for Bugs)

That's right. The game locks you into fighting one enemy type, on one biome, until everyone finally gets their act together and gangs up to actually beat them. It's even worse if you don't defeat them, since then you have to start the process of knocking them out all over again and people hate fighting the Illuminate so much that this routinely happens even though everyone knows that just prolongs the process.

On top of factions becoming locked off once they're defeated, the stratagems themselves are randomly assigned to various worlds within each factions space. Once that faction is defeated, you can no longer unlock those abilities. So, if you join the game and you want napalm bombs but they're in a defeated enemies space too bad. You can't have them until the next war, period. Long term, that isn't an issue but in the short term it's beyond annoying.


Conclusion!

So ultimately, this is a pretty fun game for a little while but if you're looking for something that has decent replay value sadly I can't recommend this.

If you want just a little casual game to fill in an hour or two a week this title may be for you, but at the same time you'll be at the mercy of the War Campaign on what you can and can't play that week.

There are so many missed opportunities in this game that it's palpable, and I think you'll see a lot of players shed this game as soon as they hit the 100-200 hour mark for all the reasons listed above unless Arrowhead start pumping out more DLC to beef up the actual content of the game beyond new Stratagem's and outfits.

There are several other issues with this game too, don't think this is a definitive list. Most of the other issues this game has I can get past, but unless something drastic and fundamental changes with this title I will likely never play it again.

reviewText:
HELLDIVERS is an incredibly fun game. If you recall Starship Troopers or Robocop (original) from Paul Verhoeven then you can imagine the exaggerated, ignorantly utopian world which is pretty much a satire for everything we know. This feeling has been delivered here by Arrowhead Game Studios in a game format, which is entertaining and addictive.

It's an isometric action shooter for 1-4 players where you are an Super Earth elite soldier battling 3 alien races throughout the galaxy sectors, with progress being accumulated by every player's contribution by completion of objectives. Which in turn leads to additional, major events.

Game has an incredible amount of weapons - from direct damage firearms, mechanized exosuits, APCs, tanks, to turrets, call-in airstrikes and technological gadgets. All of them can be upgraded by receiving research points from leveling or gathering special objectives (samples) in levels, opening new ways to use them or improve on weak points.

HELLDIVERS has 12 difficulty levels divided by planets in sectors. Every loadout slot is a tactical choice and can either compliment team composition to be able to deal with all manner of threats or strengthen individual divers.

Essentially it's an Alien Swarm meets Magicka game. Having very dynamic gameplay and challenges for all levels of skill and group compositions.

If you decide to get it - buy the full dlc version as it will save you money on individual dlc purchases where some really great items are provided (perk boots, tank, solid mid tier walker, etc).

reviewText:
It's everything I wished for.
A game heavily influenced by Starship Troopers with a dash of Warhammer 40k and Halo ODST, along with the better parts of Magicka.

You can really feel the camaraderie with your fellow Helldivers as you push through the map, taking out patrols faster than they can react. Even when everything goes south, it's a blast. Getting out of a dire situation with only you remaining, running as fast as your little legs can take you, trying to outrun the horde of certain death right behind you, and then fumbling as you try to call down reinforcement.
It's intense.

There's an absolute ton of variety with all the strategems, airstrikes and what not. Everything from calling down a nuke to a motorcycle. There are so many weapons to choose from, and they can all be upgraded. Albeit some are completely worthless and others vastly superior.
And of course, you can change how your character looks, which is always appreciated.
The only bad thing about this game that comes to mind is all the DLC. You essentially have to buy the game twice (or one and a half times if you bought that one pack) to have everything. Most of the vanilla stuff is better, but there are some exceptions.

I love it!

reviewText:
Thrilling, unpredictable, drop-in/drop-out cooperative-play focused, sci-fi twin-stick action game from Swedish developer Arrowhead Game Studios (Magicka, Gauntlet reboot), with amazing graphics, animations, special effects, sound effects and music.

It's like getting to star in your own hybrid Aliens and Starship Troopers movie at the press of a button, with a different plot and a different ending every time. :-) It feels different every time. Procedurally generated levels and mission objectives never let the game feel stale. Although if you find killing Bugs, Cyborgs and Illuminates repetitive in general, then maybe you'll find the game repetitive  -- however, I've never felt tired of its thrills. :)

A couple gameplay movies are worth a thousand of my words (hope to post more videos soon):
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=569778835
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=569500877
A diverse and fun-to-use and fun-to-watch-in-action set of weapons, hardware and stratagem attacks -- dive bombing runs, strafing attacks, multiple artillery salvos, land mines, turrets, the list goes on and on -- give you endless different loadouts for every mission.

Endless humor intended (the game's Starship Troopers'-style politics and general backstory) and unintended - drop pods will fall on you sooner or later, probably sooner and a lot often. :-)

As far as game comparisons, something like Robotron 2084, Smash TV, Total Carnage, and Alien Swarm with massive, procedurally generated outdoor environments and neverending combinations of mission objectives that prevent gameplay from ever feeling predictable. And even that description is lacking. Helldivers is really just... Helldivers imho. :-)

Helldivers Moments
Here's some of what I've done in 18 hours+ play so far (I'll update the list later):
Call in a Barrager artillery salvos strike (3-9 artillery salvos depending on upgrades) to break up a seemingly unbeatable Cyborg mass attack and gnashed my teeth when my squaddies ignore my warning and get caught in the blast.
Jump jet my railgun-sniper leap back and forth over hordes of Bugs during a Retaliatory Strike mission, trying desperately to stay alive, and call back in squaddies by reinforcment pod.
Call in repeated aircraft strafing runs in solo play to break up enemy rushes.
Been squashed flat by reinforcement and supply pods repeatedly and never failed to laugh about it. :)Putting the C" in Cooperative Play
On the co-op side:Rushed under rotary cannon fire and falling grenades to help wounded fellow Helldiver players up off the ground
date: and had many people I don't know do the same for me. It's a simple gameplay mechanic
recommended: but it's a great feeling. :-)\nhttp://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=570653555\nThe other night

reviewText:
I don't remember that much of emotion in Skype, it tops even Dota sometimes. What would you say to a friend who accidentally shoots you to death while in tank, then rolls over the gunner who was trying to get out to help and then killing himself because of tank's inertia?

The game is quite expensive, so maybe you should wait for discounts. And I can't blindly recommend it to everyone. Be aware of hardcore nature of the game - most notably friendly fire and necessity to stay together (you share the screen) and be well coordinated.

DLCs are expensive but interesting and offer some important pieces of equipment. EXO Lumberer and Tank (one driver and one shooter) are the most important ones in my opinion and I don't know ways to unlock them without buying.

Hours into the game, I still want to play it, beat harder missions and unlock more stuff.

TL;DR GOTY (2015) for online co-op with up to 4 people.

P.S. Ok, that's too many GOTYs, just the best (2015) game in its category!

reviewText:
Helldivers is a bit of an enigma, but a thoroughly enjoyable one.

For a game with such a huge amount of focus on friendly fire, (accidental) team killing and other shenanigans, it surprising how friendly and skillful the community is in general.

Not once in 50+ missions have I encountered dickish behaviour. The players are friendly, the gameplay is a whole hell of a lot of fun and the missions range from 'dive in the park' easy to absolutely insane. You will kill a lot of teammates, get killed by even more of them but at the end of every mission you're blasting away at hordes of aliens while you wait for your shuttle to extract you, with epic music blasting into your ears. What's there not to like?

Calling in supply drops with directional-pad combinations gives a great depth of skill next to the actual positioning, shooting and anticipation of the gunplay. The ability to call in mechs, turrents, heavier secondary weapons or even a 4-man APC gives the game even more depth. ♥♥♥♥, you can team up in pairs to reload anti-tank rockets faster. All the while faced by the looming threat of getting killed by bugs, dropping pods or friendly fire. This is co-op! Did I mention that you can drop into other matches (or call in other players during your own) at any moment? And the overarching community-based campaign to eradicate all other species in the name of democracy? And the boss battles?

10/10 would cape swirl again while delivering freedom.

reviewText:
***REQUIRED DLC***
Let's get this out of the way first. In order to really enjoy this game, you need at least two DLC packs with some essential equipment. (1) RANGER PACK - this unlocks an unmanned drone which is absolutely ESSENTIAL because it reveals sample locations when fully upgraded saving tons of time for farming. (2) TERRAIN SPECIALIST PACK - this gives you a perk which nullifies the slowing effects on snow and swamp planets...mobility is life. I would also recommend the optional (3) ENTRENCHED PACK, as it provides a useful anti-tank mech and barbed wire, which will save your life on retaliation strikes.

Gameplay Videos:
Solo Gameplay | Retaliation Strike Gameplay | 4-player Co-op Gameplay

Helldivers is a top-down, cooperative action game set in a generic sci-fi setting. Up to four players work together to complete objectives during missions to unlock experience points, gear, and research points to upgrade their gear. Chains of missions can be beaten to conquer planets, which feeds into the Helldivers meta-game, which is quite clever. In the meta-game, humanity is fighting a war on three fronts (corresponding to the three alien races you’ll encounter). Each front is divided into sectors, and as you conquer each sector you get closer to the enemy home planets, which when defeated knock that enemy out of the current “war”. Every planet individual players defeat contributes to the point threshold in each sector, which is conquered when the required threshold is reached. Occasionally the enemy will go on the offensive, forcing you to defend planets (and ultimately Earth). If Earth falls, the current war ends and a new war begins in a presumably alternate reality.

Helldivers requires a sense of humor. It’s designed to be played with four players, and each player is constantly calling in orbital bombardments, resupply drop pods, vehicles, and equipment. Each one of these can kill you when they enter the map. You’ll die if you stand in front of a teammate while he’s firing, if you’re too close to his mech when he walks, if you jump out of your vehicle while it’s still moving and it runs you over, if you jump off the side of a cliff, drop a grenade at your own feet, or die from the actual enemies in the game. It’s all part of the fun, but it presupposes that everyone is taking a similar, light-hearted yet directed approach to the game.

In my experience, the community is fun and welcoming, for the most part happy to work together to collect samples and complete goals. All in all, Helldivers is tremendous fun and provides excellent value. It’s a shame that several DLC are considered essential to enjoy the game to its fullest, but I suppose you can always get those on sale.

Read the full review[www.thesewall.com]. You can also view my Lone Wolf solo guide here.

reviewText:
HELLDIVERS:
~~~~~~~~~~

This is a special news broadcast from Super Earth!! Ladies and Gentleman, Super Earth is under attack! Yes, we reached out of space and discovered 3 other galactic civilizations and our initial contact was friendly. Now in 2064, we have to defend Super Earth from 3 fronts! Fortunately we have the best military units in the galaxy and you know who they are . . .  the mighty Helldivers; thank God for that!

Helldivers is an action twin stick shooter / online co-op game where you play a soldier in the famous Super Earth military unit “HELLDIVERS”.  You have to prevent Super Earth from being destroyed by three very interesting intergalactic races (Bugs, The Illuminates and Cyborgs) by taking over regions in the galaxy and by successfully defending them from their counter attacks.

When you first launch the game, you will go through a quick but thorough tutorial which give you a very good understanding of what you have to do in combat. Then you will hit the main spaceship bridge where you will be able to choose missions, weapons upgrades and the excellent “Helldivers encyclopaedia” with plenty of content.

Head up to the Galactic Campaign table; from there you will be able to see the war fronts and choose which race you would like to fight against, or just join another group in battle. There are lots of variable missions; some will be to eliminate a specific number of enemies, some will have several objectives to achieve before you go to your extraction point! You will face an infinite number of enemies in each map and your team will be using all available tricks under their sleeves to extract themselves safely.

Some of the tricks are: the “Stratagem” (which are additional gizmos you can call upon), ammo drops, defence turrets, strikes, vehicles and more. You will find samples lying on the ground; make sure to collect them as they will go towards your research points. Collect 10 samples and you will get 1 research point. Each time you level up, you will own an additional research point which you will need to upgrade your weapons and stratagems. One thing I forgot to mention is to be really careful who you shoot, as friendly fire is always on! Plenty of “Oops, sorry mate!”

If you successfully achieve your mission (objective and extraction) you will be given XP and great rewards depending in which region you fought in. Rewards could include new stratagems, weapons and more.

The graphics and animations are fabulous and the game runs brilliantly.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Great graphics
-	Fun and fast gameplay
-	Plenty of enemies – 3 different races
-	Number of upgrades and equipment
-	Different levels of difficulty (1 to 12)
-	Up to 4 player online co-op
-	Achievements

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	No trading cards

My goodness, I am hooked on HELLDIVERS! Just a splendid game!

10/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

reviewText:
This is a cool game. A little top down shooter maybe based on starship troopers. As you can see from the store page, it has a nice unique artstyle. It's extremely enjoyable, you go on short missions to advance in a war with the community, to get to the final mission and take out the home planet of either cyborgs, bugs, or ... Illuminati? idk.

The game features single co-op missions, this is not an RPG, you unlock standard guns, skills and perks. It features a system where you unlock combat deployable ablities by clearing planets, ranging from turrets that drop from orbit, to support weapons and supply drops, even attack runs from air support.

You unlock guns as you advance in rank, and some fun perks like different types of grenades and weapon enhancements. There is also something of a perk spec system, RPG like, but not RPG. You end up spending research points on weapon upgrades, and upgrading your orbit drop abilities.

There is team damage, and environment damage, super fun. Get killed by your friends, watch out for supply drops from orbit, you will get crushed, and just when you think you are out, watch the heli land on you. Fun way to spend some time with friends or kill time solo.

Priority level 93/100  (Get this game as soon as you can and play the ♥♥♥♥ out of it)

EDIT: There is a mega pack for all DLC. If you get the base game and want to upgrade later, it costs 12.5% more total than the DDE. Just keep it in mind. No the DLC does not cost 40 to buy all of it. So buy the DDE or take the risk of paying 12.5% more later.

reviewText:
HellDivers is a Hardcore, 4-player co-op, top-down shooter that seems to be a hybrid of Alien Swarm, Magicka, and Diablo. Thematically, you'll be reminded of every Sci-Fi trope that you can imagine as you travel around the galaxy, meet new and interesting species, and act as an ambassador of Democracy. Think.... Starship troopers.

Positives:
+The action and gameplay of shooting up aliens as a spaceman is very well done.
+The progression system system is very well-done. Leveling is as you'd expect- get levels, unlock skins and weapons. Players can also unlock new strategems (powers) by playing through a series of missions successfully. Lastly, players must accrue research points (through leveling and collecting samples on maps) to upgrade their gear. This is a sort of talent tree for your character.
+Equipping your character individually, as well as a team, presents a lot of interesting and meaningful choices. You only have 4 strategem (power) slots, a weapon, and perk (big power) that you can equip. Much of the fun is the trial and error of different loadouts for you and for your team.
+There is a huge variety of weaponry. Most of the weapons are different enough that there's not really a 'super weapon' but rather weapons that fit a specific roll or style.
+There is a massive variety of powers that you can unlock. Think of Guild Wars/Guild Wars 2 - the possibilities are immense.
+The combined arms aspect of the game is well-done.
+BIG ROBOTS that you can use to spread Democracy.

Negatives:
-There are occasionally steam network/game connectivity issues. If you disconnect from a mission,  you lose your progress in collecting science samples (which are really important.)
-You absolutely must stay on the same screen as your teammates. This can get a little hectic/difficult if your cursors are scattered all over the place, constraining your ability to see what's going on around you.
-The controls can be a little hard to master. Your mouse cursor will move faster than your characters/turrets can turn. Ultimately, there's some balance to this... but many PC players will find this to be a bit sluggish.
-When playing with randoms, there is a (small) potential that you will encounter a hacker; reportedly, a hacker can increase your XP/science points to max, somewhat thwarting your progression.

Overall, this is a great game to play with your buddies looking for a Coop game, or with random folks and pubbies. The action is good, and there is a lot of value in the hilarious wipes that you'll surely incur.

reviewText:
HELLDIVERS is pretty cool, I guess.

Created by the team behind Magicka, a game that destroys friendships, comes another game that destroys friendships.

Set in the distant future of next Thursday, HELLDIVERS, as my Steam library likes to shout at me, is a game about humanity at war. You are a HELLDIVER, a type of orbital shock unit that gets into little pots and fired at planets like angry genocide bullets. Super Earth is in danger! Threatened on all sides by evil alien threats, the HELLDIVERS must lead the spearhead from planet to planet, conquering and annihilating all opposition in your way so you can indoctrinate and exploit your enemies harshly and go back to your way of life of being spied on by the government and using dead bodies as food.

Wait, are we the bad guys?

HELLDIVERS is a strictly multiplayer game, sure you can go in lone wolf but much like my ex wife, it kills most of the fun and forces you to live out your days living in your own refuse.  Unlike many games with a war narrative, HELLDIVERS is entirely about the war, where you and thousands of other players march from planet to planet and conquer them in the name of Super Earth, taking over sector after sector until you can reach your enemies home world and knock them out of the war for good. And when all three enemy races have a Burger King on their home world, the war is won and the game resets! Letting you and your HELLDIVER comrades start from square one.

But the real meat of HELLDIVERS is the actual game play. After picking a planet and the location of the planet you want to attack, you're introduced to a top down stick shooter with various objectives for you and your three squad mates to accomplish. Now, I'm not a fan of twin stick shooters, they are to me what Carlos Mencia is to comedy, that is to say they don't click. But I ended up actually really enjoying HELLDIVERS, all of the weapons had this very crunchy kick to them and it was satisfying to rip cyborgs and bugs to shreds under a hail of gunfire.

HELLDIVERS also has the advantage of letting you customize your load out, taking down with you not only perks and weapons, but also vehicles, defensive emplacements, and even tertiary support like air strikes and orbital bombardment. The game play compliments the war-time narrative, by making you feel like an actual fighting force rather than a hero unit with an objective.

Another thing that lets HELLDIVERS stand out from other twin-stick shooters is that it isn't a horde mode game. Many games of it's natures just have you mow down wave after wave of enemies until they finally get you, tallying up the wave you killed and giving you a score much like getting a gold medal with chocolate inside in elementary school for participating in track and field. While HELLDIVERS does indeed have a game mode like that, even that one has a kill limit. Your goal in HELLDIVERS is to complete your objectives and then escape the planets surface without being completely overrun by your enemy.

Even though I liked HELLDIVERS, I like it the same way you like eating fast food or smoking crack, it's good but you shouldn't be doing it all the time. Due to it's nature, HELLDIVERS is a very repetitive game, there isn't much variety in missions and all the difficulty levels do is add more objective while throwing more dirty alien commie scum ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s at you. But I don't think HELLDIVERS is meant to be played all day every day, more like you put a good number of hours in when you first get it, and after that you just kind of play it from time to time.

There are other things I can criticize about the game that isn't really the games fault. Like the one guy who doesn't know what friendly fire is, or that other guy who will drop equipment at the worst places, or THAT ONE GUY WHO DOESNT REALIZE THAT WE ALL SHARE THE SAME CAMERA AND SHOULD PROBABLY STICK WITH THE GROUP INSTEAD OF DRAGGING HIS FACE ACROSS THE SIDE OF THE SCREEN LIKE A VERY OPTIMISTIC WINDOW SHOPPER.

ISNT THAT RIGHT, CARL?

But should you play HELLDIVERS?

If you think a narrative can carry what is essentially a repetitive but quality twin-stick shooter, than yeah. The game feels good and is fun to play in short bursts, and there are enough references to classic science fiction series to enjoy. There is also a hella amount of DLC but they aren't necessary to do good and don't really make much of a difference in the long run. As a base game, HELLDIVERS is a fun time waster with a narrative and reward system that makes it feel good to accomplish the task at hand.

BUTTJUMPERS gets 7 Starship Troopers references out of 10.

Pumpkin spice lattes can increase the chance of getting cancer.

The curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J1LONIP-Moo

HELLDIVERS is a co-op two stick shooter with a galactic military strategy theme. This game was very well received by the Playstation community and has finally come to the PC. The game has several elements that make it really shine including planetary domination and eventual galactic conquest. The instanced feel of each encounter makes it easy to pick up and play for any period of time. The controls for the PC are just not workable so having a controller for this is the one major hiccup if you don't already own one.

What I enjoyed:
Dropping in – I liked that you sort of set your own fate in multiple aspects. You choose where to fly and begin your conquest. Once in a system you choose which planet and mission to take. You get to place your drop pod anywhere on the map for the instance you enter on the planet, which can be a blessing or a curse as you see in my video. The feeling that you are in control of your own fate with so many facets is certainly a unique and fun mechanic incorporated into the entire experience.
Environmental planets – Each planet I dropped into had different themes, all which fit the entire art style and “space travel” story line  exceptionally well. The environments are also dynamic and certain ones have lava explosions or other hazards that can kill your Helldiver. I ran into some lava on a bug infested planet and it wasn't pleasant. The variation in planet type and environmental atmospheres is done well enough that the feeling of travel and exploration is felt strongly.
Shoot up some aliens – Shooting aliens and taking over planets is fun. I really enjoy a game that has a simple style like this, incorporated into a bigger overall picture. The combat is dual stick and these are the same designers of “Magicka” so be prepared for a frustrating situation here or there, but mostly it comes down to managing your mobs, and if in co-op, managing your team well.

What I disliked:
Controller Required – If a game comes to the PC, it should have a workable control scheme right out of the box. I found the default to be just awful, and honestly for a two stick shooter you need a controller. I have one so it was not that big of a roadblock, but for someone without a PC stick, this could be very annoying.
Missed shots – I felt like at times my bullets sort of passed through certain mobs rather than killed them, which caused a death here and there. It may be that there is a miss percentage, or that you've got to line right up to their center. I think this was the only major area of combat that felt like it could use some work.

A two stick shooter like this with co-op for a few friends is certainly something worth looking at. I enjoyed playing it and can't wait for release to spend some time with the co-op. It's already been highly reviewed by the Playstation crowd, so I'm affirming that it's a fun game and if you didn;t get to play it on the PS3 or PS4, you should pick it up for the PC.
Score: Buy it now

reviewText:
Despite what a lot of the negative reviews are saying, there's a bundled DLC option that gives you all the packs for a discount, which compared to the collector's edition is only about $5 USD more expensive. It's not very visible on the main page, you can find it by clicking on an individual piece of DLC and looking at the related items. I definitely don't think this game deserves negative reviews for having a slightly misleading Steam page (may not even be the devs fault, and they seem to be extremely passionate about this game).

That aside, the game is an extremely fun coop twin stick shooter, reminiscent of Left4Dead and Alien Swarm. I've been playing with random people and I've been having as much fun as I've had with friends (even moreso sometimes). It's unforgiving in its difficulty and it's a pleasure to play. Finding the right load out and strategies for the different varieties of planets and missions is a real challenge. The netcode is rock solid (compared to the cluster♥♥♥♥ that Magicka online was), and the developers seem relatively active in patching and releasing new content (it's been out for a year on PSN and has had two major updates, plus the DLC).

Having a bunch of the content locked behind DLC is a little concerning, but I've bought a few pieces and it doesn't seem to give me a huge advantage over the base content. They're pretty much sidegrades, and anyone who hasn't bought the DLC will have a great and competitive time regardless. The top review (at the moment) cites the tank as something you can't get without buying the DLC. It's true, but the tank is also remarkably useless compared to other strategies. I suppose if you really really want to drive a tank you're stuck for options, but it's by no means a pay to win scenario.

reviewText:
LIBERTY FOR ALL!
Helldivers is a frantic 4 player cooperative twin stick shooter that lets you and your friends play the role of space marines fighting against swarms of bugs, cyborgs, and robots. Every aspect of its design is polished and it feels very responsive; and this is important because Helldivers is a very punishing game but rarely does it frustate. More often then not death and failure occurs can always be avoided; but mistakes and oversights will result in scenarios that can be both hilarious and frustartingly tense. At the same time, with coordination and planning it's possible to pull off satisfying high strategy maneuvers that can pull your team out of a dire situation and win games. There is a lot of strategy in this game, especially if you're able to find a few friends to coordinate with.

Even at the base price, there is a satisfying amount of equipment avaiable from weaspons, perks, and a selection of special utility items called stratagems that help specialise and differentiate your helldiver from the squad. strategems can range from defensive items like land mines to automatic turrets; offensive items like orbital stikes and missle barrages; and specialized equipment like jetpacks and vehicles. Futher more, a satisfying progression system allows weapons and stratagems to be further improved by spending research points on them.

Presentation and theme goes along away to making this game's feel as well. Weapons and vehicles look and feel as powerful as you'd expect them to. Helldivers themselves are heavily stylised and will shout out corny one liners while they relentlessly tear through waves of bad guys without questioning their orders spread the glorious concepts of freedom and democracy around the galaxy. It's a fun universe to play in, even if there's not much in the way of story here (It would just get in the way of freedom anyway).

The only caveat is regarding the DLC. Just know that when choosing to buy the base game, you'll be missing out on some cool equipment. While none of it is really needed to enjoy the game; some of the tools and weapons provided are very useful. I'd personally reccomend going with the Digital Deluxe edition if you can afford to because it includes all the DLC. It's not listed on the store page as of this review there is a DLC pack that offers all the DLC for $25 as opposed to purchasing it all separately. This is the only thing that is questionable, but I think for the amount of content you get and the gameplay at hand, $40 is a fair price.
voteText: 16 of 17 people (94%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Helldivers is a great little gem, not afraid to show its inspirations on its sleeve, and not taking itself too seriously. Helldivers still manages to create a brutal, intense and frantic gameplay, surprising with the variety on multiple levels, the tactics, the enemies, the planets, the tools and the randomness mixing things up a bit.

A top-down shooter, with pure fun, lots of death, hectic fights with good effects and animations, different tactics, missions, planets, enemies, weapons, almost all unique and fun, though still inspired.
The game has an interesting setup, with the player on a spaceship dreadnought bridge, where you can upgrade equipment, study an encyclopedia (IMPORTANT!), mess about and prepare for the Helldrop, the coop works well and you can join your friends easily on their bridge or in the middle of a mission, talk tactics and coordinate on what equipment to take on the drop, where to drop and what to focus on.
This game feels like a massive scale galactic campaign, and it doesn't even have a story, but it manages to create that feeling via the galactic map where you can see how other helldivers are attacking on what fronts, the mission structures and how planets and difficulties affect the influence in the war effort on that front.
It would be a nice finishing touch to have some missions, like defending capital cities or the final push on the enemy homeworld, played out more like a war and not an op, to have npc marines follow you and your squad into a push on entrenched enemy positions, and have enemies swarm some extraction point with you and npc marines setting up a defense.
There are other areas where the game gives impressions on how to improve and add to create an even more enriching, immersive and fun experience, but still, the game is great already as it is. If only modding would exist for this game.

Some inspirations to note:
Alien Swarm, the free source-engine mod/game here on steam, but Helldivers manages to build upon the gameplay a lot.
Aliens, obviously.
Starship Troopers, in the strange dystopian cheesy atmosphere and bughunts.
Warhammer 40k, also to some degree in the setting, atmosphere and some design choices.
Halo, with the cheesy but fun and colourful action and vast battlefields, many different enemies with different behaviours, weapons, styles and scales.
As a PC port, it feels excellent, the mouse and keyboard work well, the system requirements are reasonable, not really many graphics options to tweak, but still, it looks great and the options you can change are probably the ones people can have different tastes about. The online and local coop work well and are very straight-forward, the esc menu clearly states your privacy settings and push-to-talk options, the bridge is the hub for your decisions on joining in on other players or selecting your own missions or customizing your character etc.

The DLC was made after the game was released on the different PS platforms, so it misleadingly looks like day one dlc on steam, when it wasn't originally available on day one. It makes sense to have the already full and complete fun game for a reasonable price, with the option to buy in different packs the dlcs which are also fun and varied, also useful and can make life easier, but not adding pay to win" elements into the game."

reviewText:
This is review is on point (I have played the game for 100 hours + on the PS3, I am a lvl 27 helldiver). THIS GAME IS AMAZING! A 9/10 easily. Lets start with graphics and sound. Both the graphics and sound are flawless. The aliens sound and look like aliens should for their particular race. The explosions/dust particles/weapons fire/environments/planets themselves and all other aspects involving graphics and sound are fantastic. I have ZERO complaints about that!

Now, lets talk about the gameplay. The gameplay mechanics are for, without a doubt, hardcore coop players. If you are not a team player, you will find it difficult to make it through the game alone (but it can be done). Friendly fire is 100% and can NOT be turned off, the game was designed this way for intense fights and epic battles where you and your team have nothing but coordination and cooperation to survive the mission. THIS GAME IS NOT EASY! Enemies are endless and will constantly spawn. You do not get xp for kills. You will find a large learning curve when you first start out. However, you will enjoy it as you can't help to admire the beauty as your entire team struggles to make it out of certain, impossible situations alive. My one complaint about the game is the strategems. Strategems are how helldivers call in equipment/bombing runs/defensive structures/ect from space. These take time to arrive (some are faster than others) and you WILL ABSOLUTELY USE THESE! ALL OF THE STRATEGEMS ARE AWESOME! However, my complaint rests with certain strategems eventually becoming useless or out of date. Do not let this discourage you though. That is just my opinion. EVERYONE will find a strategem they feel is pointless but other players will use quite often because everyone is different in how they play the game. It is important to know you need to pick your strategems based around the objectives and what your team is choosing to use. Another mechanic that is worth discussing is the weapon stats and description. THERE IS NO SUPERIOR WEAPON IN THIS GAME! WHICH IS AMAZING! Every weapon has its pros and its cons and the statistics on the each weapon are to the letter. If a gun has low stability but heavy power, it will perform as such. If the gun has high rate of fire but long reload time, it shows in the game. This mechanic is very well done and worth highlighting as other games have weapon statistics but sometimes the weapons all the feel the same (a good example is *cough* EA battlefront *cough*).

Now lets talk about story (my only real complaint): There is very little story.... AH WHO AM I FOOLING! THERE IS STORY!!! You are helldiver spreading democracy and FREEDOM! AND LIBERTEA!!! but thats about it. But in reality, that is all you need. The missions you go on with your best friends and how you survived a near death experience will create stories. Those are the best kind of stories in my opinion. I enjoyed discussing over chat on how we were completely surrounded without our backs to backs and we still made it out by the skin on our teeth.

In summary: this game is fantastic, buy it and get your friends to buy it. I RECOMMEND IT 100%!
Good luck recruits and to the veterans of PS3 transferring to PC, ILL SEE YOU ON THE FIELD FOR FREEDOM!!"

reviewText:
A well-made, fun co-op game with core gameplay that I quite enjoy. Ordinarily this would easily earn a recommend from me. However, in this case there really are a few things that hold the game back.

1) The grind. Dear lord. I'm 29 hours in, having played hard and well, and I haven't unlocked all the base items. Some of them are very important to play the harder difficulties. This is compounded by there being only a very small number of mission types, and aside from terrain most maps play the same.
2) The camera system is incredibly obnoxious.
3) DLC is both expensive and necessary. The harder difficulties almost require them, and the community is turning toxic - I've been kicked from games because I don't have certain DLCs, which is unacceptable.

Of the three reasons, the third was the point where I realised I cannot recommend this game. Please avoid unless you're willing to shell out additional money to get the full" game experience."

reviewText:
(TL, DR at bottom, no spoilers)
This is THE best game I've played in long time. It's unforgiving and the co-op is SOLID.

12 levels of difficulty that suits people who either have never even touched a computer and those who likes to constantly suffer for 2 hours, and still not complete the mission. Even on higher difficulty the game never gets boring if you got 3 good team mates to play with, which you will find regularly even when joining random games.

I'm not gonna lie though. You WILL die. Hilariously often even. And mostly of stupid mistakes too! Or because drop pods sometimes seems to home in on friendlies.

So all in all, this game fits everyone who enjoys a nice community, lots of unlocks, stupid deaths, solid and thought through co-op gameplay, Starship Troopers, occasional mutilation by drop-pod and soulsucking defeat for a single mistake. <3

TL, DR:
You will get killed by friendly drop pods. EVERY. GAME. 10/10 would play again though.
